she blinded me with science  

editor's note: there will be much geek contact in this evening's post, because that's what i've been doing a lot lately. non-geek readers may prefer to wait to hear about the minneapolis/st. paul visit early next week...

there are going to be some major changes to this web site soon... i've spent some time the last few days learning postnuke, php/mysql-based content management system of php-nuke progeny. it's got plenty of features i don't need, but lots that i want and need. (for example, i'm quite impressed with the gallery web-based photo album, which acts as a postnuke module/block. since i've got this digital camera i have all these pictures from africa, events with friends, etc. that need to get posted for others to see.) so i'm almost ready to roll it up to the real webserver, although i'll have to use someone else's free theme graphics until i have time to create my own.

i also geeked out some more this morning in upgrading to the latest version of snort on the win32 laptop (see installation tips from silicon defense). i also started using pack-x's ids center, which i don't think i've looked at for a while but am now quite impressed. highly recommended if you're using "the pig" on win32 (the other pig).

well, i should be off to bed now, as ains & i are flying to the twin cities tomorrow. keith is kindly driving us to beantown around 7:45am, and all 3 of us in the house will be vying for the bathroom before then. (that may be one advantage of having my own apartment, hopefully soon).

back in the u.s.s.r.  

as the beatles sang, "you don't know how lucky you are, boy!" well, admittedly, i'm not back in the area-formerly-known-as-the-soviet-union, but back is the u-s-of-a. and, moreso, i've been back for a while now... since the beginning of september, actually. furthermore, i don't believe in luck, but i do believe in a God who loves me very much.

apologies to you adoring fans (both of you) and to my future self, as this blog is probably as much for me to remember the past as it is for a few now distant friends who like to keep up on my whereabouts. since i haven't been working since i returned, i can't really say i have an excuse, other than the fact that i've been semi-homeless and hopping from house to house, some with 'net connectivity and some without. but really, i just didn't know what to say...

i'm still mentally processing the trip to africa, and when people ask about it i just don't know what to say. the usual response is, "yeah, it was amazing... God really met us there and worked wonders in us and around us." that's the short of it, at least. we really enjoyed the time and the tasks, in particular meeting the people and gaining some family out there; and we want so much to return each summer if the Lord wills. and truly if anything worthwhile was accomplished while we were there, god did the work and not us, because it was fully evident that we had nothing of value to offer but our willingness to let the Spirit work through us. and ainsley and i returned as two different people than when we left, having been transformed by a renewed faith in Jesus' power and love. i guess you could say we're "Jesus freaks" now.

the days since returning have been interesting. since i moved all my stuff into storage and moved out of my apartment at the end of july, i've been trying not to wear out my welcome with the marvelous group of friends who've been putting me up (or rather, putting up with me) for so long: troy & maegan, dave (& kim), and lance and keith. although living out of a suitcase for so long is frustrating, it's been a lot of fun to build relationships with these friends.

you may also remember what i used to call my "rare tropical disease"... no surprise that it's not a tropical disease (because i had it before i ever went to the tropics), and if it's what we think it is, it's not too rare either. many of the symptoms both from this year and previous incidents of digestive troubles point to crohn's disease. (to find out more, check out this introduction or this site for tons of info). hopefully, the gastoenterologist should be getting the results from last weeks' "ugi with small bowel follow-through" x-rays soon, then we'll be able to figure out what's going on or what to do next.

as for the unemployment: i was just starting to get a bit worried, and now there's a couple opportunities coming down the pike. i may go to maryland for 3 weeks or so for a short contract doing lotus notes development and assisting with firewall deployment. and the guys at my old consulting firm the computer merchant think that the market for contract work will be picking up in december and january, so that would be great. and, in the category of fun distractions, i might even help out moving hay bales at a standish farm over the next couple weeks: some good healthy physical labor would be great.

ains & i have done and will be doing more than a bit of travelling. last weekend we drove out to mentor, ohio, for a family gathering in which i got scrutinized by ainsley's cousins and her aunt's friends (i think i passed). this coming weekend we're flying to the twin cities to check out bethel seminary and area churches and businesses. then we should be with her parents for turkey day and a wedding. (and maybe ainsley's family will come out to join my family in camden for christmas—how cool is that?!?)

<note-to-self>to-do list for the upcoming days:
  • get background checks and drug tests for the maryland job
  • write thank-you letters to all the folks who supported me for the africa trip
  • get a new credit card so i can take advantage of a balance transfer to tide me over until the job money starts coming in
  • look for an apartment
  • update my website with postnuke (really! this time i mean it!)
that's not even the half of it, really, but it's a start anyway...</note-to-self>

i think that's more than enough blabbering for today. perhaps in the coming days i can share more amusing stories of the latest adventures or even journal entries from the time in rwanda. (or maybe i'll get too busy working on other stuff.)

album-of-the-day >>> grassroots music distribution's dialects, vol. 1: folk/americana <<< over the past few months i've found some great christian music recommendations at grassroots, so i picked up this sampler of folkish folks. i like it.

airbag  

<countdown>22 hours until we leave portland. everything's falling together—of course i knew god could make it all happen, but i'd be lying if i said i wasn't worrying about all the details these past two weeks. i'm so excited; this is going to be so marvelous. don't forget to pray for us!</countdown>

today has been a fine, productive day. it started at 5am (ouch) so i could have some time to pack before going to the men's breakfast at my church (combined with the man club) at 7. the fellowship was quite encouraging, and the good high-protein breakfast was well fit for the work ahead. then a handful of guys helped me out with the rest of the packing and all of the moving to storage: alan (my boss, isn't he great?), tom (from my church and the men's ministry committee), keith (who helped me a ton on monday, too), ken (who didn't think he would be in town), and troy (who stayed home this weekend specifically to help me out!). we finished it up a couple of hours ago, and now the house is nearly empty, excepting my luggage, cleaning materials, empty boxes, and myself... wow. i'm so grateful that these guys could help me out, and i'm feeling supported and encouraged now.

btw, keep praying for my friends nathan and karen—this coming wednesday they are going to take their nine-month old daughter anna to the children's hospital in boston for brain surgery. there'll be a week of observation with wires actually going into her skull and monitoring different parts of her brain to determine the extent of the defect, and then next wednesday they intend to operate and remove whatever is necessary, up to her entire left hemisphere. obviously, this is frightening for both parents and child, as well as friends and family. but they have a strong faith in the lord's goodness and his wisdom in choosing what he will, and i know that will sustain them and glorify our lord their hope. if the lord wills, perhaps in a couple weeks anna will be seizure-free and developing normally, and we would praise him for it.

i have no idea if this will be the last post for a while now or not, as i don't know how often and how much i might have internet access from kigali. but i'll try, i really will, as i know a few of you are eager to hear the news in realtime. either way, you'll definitely hear from me in september (unless of course you never visit this page again, in which case i don't blame you)...

album-of-the-day >>> peter mulvey's ten thousand mornings <<< i'm so glad this arrived so i could hear it before i leave the country and the cd collection behind... it's another live album (recorded in the subways of boston), and he is so good live. he also covers so great songs from other artists such as gillian welch, dar williams, etc. and when he covers someone else's song he really makes it his own. highly recommended.

waterfall  

<countdown>3 days until we leave for africa... i have my tickets right here. the empty and full boxes are piling up in my apartment, and the storage shed now has its first few contents. it seems that i've scheduled every remaining hour of the next few days (and that doesn't include sleep!).</countdown>

my boss let me take a couple technical certification tests just before i leave the company as a "resume builder" of sorts—these were tests where i already knew the content pretty darn well from several years of real-world experience, but it might help to have the certificate to back it up. last week i took and passed team database's new database industry exam, and today i passed the ciw foundations exam. that means i can now add certified database industry specialist and ciw associate to my titles. (and btw i quickly reviewed the altogether lousy ciw foundations for dummies at epinions, too.)

at noon today we had the first (and last) pre-trip preparation meeting, and it went really well. tim wah-luc kept us on task and organized while we discussed the specifics of our goals and roles while we are there. when mutima greeted me as the "chief of staff", i knew i should be worrying a bit, and sure enough it was a hint that i had been selected as the team leader for the four of us who are leaving on monday, and reporting directly to sebastien while we're in-country. although it's humbling, i'm excited for the challenge, and glad that god has prepared me with helpful experiences in the past (for example, since we'll be working out a lot of the details of how to run the reconciliation conferences smoothly and train others to keep up the work, i'm thrilled to have the youth conference co-director experience in my background.)

well, i should get back to work, as i have miles to go before i sleep...

album-of-the-day >>> victoria williams and the loose band this moment—live in toronto <<< victoria is the annie dillard of the music world, and this is a great live set. she is charming and funny and real, and the whole band works together for a free-wheelin' fun sound.

congratulations  

i'm so worn out... spent the day in the sun and water for the "nsme infrastructure summer gathering 2002", which was conveniently scheduled so that ains & i could go before we left. totally enjoyed chatting with everyone, playing with and laughing at all the kids, and going crazy on rich's waverunners. (i was almost at 50mph on that thing—sheesh, i didn't even know they could go that fast!) pictures are ensuing (this was the first day i could use my new digital camera), but i'm too lazy right now.

as a "parting gift" they gave me a leatherman wave engraved with my name and "nsc infrastructure / july 2002". (i'll admit it's not as cool as my gerber urban legend, but it will be just as handy.) they got the idea because rich got a similar one for his 5-year-employee gift at national, and since i was a contractor for more than half of my 5 years there, it seemed to fit. and, incidentally, i dropped the dang thing on my big toe a few minutes ago, and it's still hurting.

i should get to bed, as i haven't been getting nearly enough sleep this week. and to help me to sleep i have the first "for dummies" book i've read (ciw foundations for dummies, most recommended for studying/reviewing for the exam i'll be taking next week). believe it or not, i find this "dummies-books" series more boring than a real, meaty computer book from o'reilly press, for example... this book is so redundant and repetative and reduplicative (you can say that again!) and not in the least bit funny. oh well, it'll get the job done.

album-of-the-day >>> juliana hatfield's only everything <<< only $2.99 (used) at newbury comics the other day... couldn't pass that up! juliana's a fine songwriter and pretty darn good on the guitar, too.

you have redeemed my soul  

this just in from the ever-present slashdot:

  • the red swingline stapler (from the inspiring movie office space) is available for purchase! i hope someone gets me one as a going-away present... ;^)
  • the excellent ray-tracing software pov-ray v3.5 has been released.

<countdown>mutimha got our plane tickets yesterday, so the official dates are july 22nd thru august 31st. that's two days earlier than i was expecting—yowsers! but god has been sooo good... the tickets were like half the price we were expecting, so the fund-raising dollars will go a long way not only to get us there but also to fill the critical operating budget fund (out of which the salaries for mutimha, sebastien and the loan officers are paid, when there's enough money). and my landlord just called to say that he found someone to take my apartment as soon as i'm gone, so i won't have to pay a month of pointless rent. hopefully the syzygus folks will be able to help me move everything to storage next saturday, and i can clean the apartment on sunday, and around 5am monday we'll be off to boston. amazing, really!</countdown>

i developed a really old roll of film the other day (the pictures spanned a year and a half!) and there were some fun ones in there, including a wonderful picture of ains & me. also, on a boring winter evening a while back i had taken a couple shots for the mirror project, and they were accepted here and here (the latter one is much cooler, don't you think?).

well, i've got a huge list of phone calls to make, and ten minutes until my next appointment, so here goes...

you are so good to me  

<countdown>8 work days left (i need to use 2 "floater" holidays in the next 2 weeks—those will come in handy!), and roughly 18 days until we lift off. last night ains & i had a good talk about my fears and unwillingness to get all the stuff done that needs to be done before i go, and now i'm pretty motivated to get going on it all. and that's part of what i'm doing today...</countdown>

<geek stuff>of course, i had to do just a little bit more geeky stuff before i go, so i'm finally following through on my goal of installing linux on my laptop. i gave up on debian due to their perhaps "retension" and reluctance to get moving... i mean, i appreciate and desire stability in the os, but i also need a current version of xfree86 and want kde 3.x, and i don't want to sacrifice other stability by running sid. so i gave up waiting for woody (i.e. the "testing" release to be named "stable"), and decided to try gentoo. i'm so glad i did! i discovered them when i realized that i know a couple of the developers from college, so i figured i'd see why they'd attach themselves to this lesser-known but up-and-coming distro. it's primary distinguishing feature is a bsd-like ports-based method for software distribution (called portage), which is an advantage both in ease of use and in performance and efficiency (and anyone who knows me will agree that i'm all about efficiency). so far the installation has gone sooo smoothly, and the system is compiling the core stuff right now as i type, and i'm sooo impressed. stay tuned for more raving about gentoo!</geek stuff>

it's been so hot and humid here lately, and now it's just started raining beautiful, big, heavy drops. oh, let it pour! i guess it's winter in the southern hemisphere now and there's a bit of draught in central africa, so it shouldn't be too bad in kigali (our "home base" during our stay). this weather.com page sometimes has the stats—temps in the 70's and 80's with low humidity doesn't look bad at all.

album-of-the-day >>> 100 portraits' and waterdeep's enter the worship circle: first circle <<< this may be, in fact, the first "worship music" recording i've liked. ainsley's friend jennifer introduced us to it when we were in ohio a few weeks ago, and now i've got my own copy... it's so simple—no-frills guitar and hand percussion—but the words are spot-on scripture-inspired. i'm starting the second loop through the disc now

sledgehammer  

strike that from this morning's entry: i have now talked with my landlord, finally. and i'll be darned if he didn't say, "well, if you had notified me sooner it would be easier to find someone to take the apartment for august..."—that's why i've been calling him every other day for three weeks now! at least he admitted it was partially his fault, and is going to try to get a tenant by august to save me wasting that month's rent.

i got a haircut after work tonight, super-short so it will maybe last through the end of the africa trip. since my regular stylist is out on maternity leave, it's always a crap-shoot when i go, and i cross my fingers hoping that "bonnie" won't be cutting my hair. but hey—she wasn't even there tonight, so it worked out just fine.

i broke down and ordered the digital camera i've been eyeing for months (the canon powershot s200), in time for the africa trip. my boss owns its predecessor, the s100, and is obsessed with it, and rightfully so, as it's a darn good camera, and most of the reviews agree that canon is winning the consumer-grade digital camera wars by a long shot (no pun intended). buy.com had the best prices and dependability, although nextag listed some better deals from unreputable companies. i'm so excited—new toys!

i should go to bed... tomorrow will be a long day of celebrating our nation's independance while keeping an eye on the skies, if george w. bush's "intelligence" sources are to be believed! (relevancy link)

dragging hooks  

<countdown>12 work days (after today); approximately 3 weeks until we're africa-bound. i still haven't been able to speak with my landlord about vacating the apartment before i leave, and i still haven't packed a single box (although i've sold or donated off some junk). i'm finding it hard to believe.</countdown>

i had the most delightful weekend, starting with friday night's first session of couple counselling with ainsley, where we began the discussion and learning of more "tools" for aiding communication, etc. in our relationship. then saturday i had most of the morning and afternoon to myself, including 14 miles on the bike and an hour in the sun; then in the evening ains & i went to a "pre-wedding celebration dinner" at the somewhat-hoaky dimillo's floating restaurant. the little jewish wedding, complete with huppa and souvenir yarmulkes, was just beautiful, and the following contradancing and visiting with ainsley's friends from chicago's contradancing scene was so much fun. afterwards we even made it to syzygus at sara's house for a little bit of jamming-to-the-oldies (a.k.a. "hymns") on the guitar, banjo and mandolin. with a weekend like that, i'm sure you'll have no trouble imagining the difficulty i had getting up for work monday morning...

and then monday morning didn't turn out too bad after all, as my parents were leaving for their vacation and stopped by to drop off what mom had prepared for sending out my "support letter" for the africa trip... it was so cool, not only had mom prepared the envelopes with all the addresses of friends and relatives she thought would be good to send to, but she had written an article for her church's newsletter about how she feels about me going to africa, and she included it in the envelopes. the conclusion of her article was, essentially, "there's no place safer than in the center of god's will." right on, mom—and thanks!

a co-worker from corporate's infosec group is now including this footer in all his emails. i find it more than a bit amusing, even as i'm the security-freak and infosec whistle-blower at my site. (if you get bored reading it, skip to the last sentence for the best laugh.):

never launch attachments inside email, even email from me. always detach and scan the file for virus infection first. never open attachments from people you do not know. check with the sender before saving attachments you did not expect, even from people you know. if this message is digitally signed, any attachment should be safe to detach. when in doubt about security or possible security problems, call me or anyone else in information security for guidance. call xxx-xxxx to report any security incident that is currently in progress. a "false" alarm is better than no alarm at all. these warnings must be attached to every copy of this document. remember that cassandra was right.

album-of-the-day >>> cowboy junkie's open <<< skip the first track, listen to the rest. you'll be glad you did.

like spinning plates  

i decided to use my k5 diary as a scratch board for the day's poetic-type musings. i don't know if this is a good idea, so read today's entry and answer the poll question, if you will.

album-of-the-day >>> radiohead's i might be wrong: live recordings <<< some of these live cuts from kid a/amnesiac are well worth the effort; on the other hand, i think they go to far into making a mess of some of the songs. you make the call.

e-bow the letter  

ainsley & i had a marvelous weekend up at my parents', and in particular enjoyed speaking about our upcoming africa trip at the evening service at dad's church. mungu asifiwe, ainsley has over two-thirds of her support already! on the other hand, i've done very little asking for money, so i have very little raised with one month to go (we'll probably leave a month from yesterday, in fact). but i trust that god will work it out, even with the job problems and all that—i believe this is important to him as well, not just to us. anyway, tonight i must write some sort of support letter to send to a few people (if you're reading this and you want a copy, email me (see the "sendmail" link at the left).

<geek-stuff>

  • i finally broke the 30,000 barrier in distributed.net's top users overall! oh oh, how should I celebrate? if you're really bored, take a look at my stats page...
  • i was just updating my html-kit app, which is a windoze web page editor (not just html but php, cf, etc.) that's free for personal use, and it's targetted for the knowledgeable user (read: real code, not gu-ey). i've had it on my work computer for a while, but haven't really taken advantage of it—but there is plenty to take advantage of. recommended for all you web-codeheads.
  • the other day i joined a new group called team database, partially inspired by their new db industry cert test and partly aided by the charter member price. they sound like they've got their heads screwed on right, so i hope they stick around a while.
</geek-stuff>

ains & i might take mutima's kids to see lilo & stitch tonight, maybe even at the drive-in. i'd seen the reviews a while back and thought it'd be fun, but now i've heard that the soundtrack is all elvis songs, and i'm piped!

album-of-the-day >>> green plastic radiohead audio <<< live clips, unreleased songs, earlier versions of the songs we now know and love... this is the rh fan's dream...

ricochet in time  

there are plenty of things i should be doing right now, including writing a support letter for my africa trip, updating my resume, paying bills, doing laundry and packing for the weekend at my parents' house, getting ready for bed so i actually get enough sleep today and maybe could get up early enough for a bike ride in the morning, and so on... but no, i'm doing really useful things like cleaning out the pile of mail on the kitchen table and sorting through my yahoo! mail account... at least i'm being somewhat productive! i had a good session with my counsellor this morning on dealing with my tendency towards procrastination... so i wonder if i'm merely trying to fool myself now? sometimes i confuse me...

uh-oh... the lexx series 3 dvd's are out now. i didn't discover the sci-fi channel's show lexx until the third season anyway, but quickly became addicted... and then i moved out of the apartment and haven't even considered getting cable again. the show's earlier seasons just didn't have the same bite, so i haven't been much interested in them... but the catchy storyline and the excellent cinematography of season 3 and beyond was worthwhile (and you don't catch me recommending tv shows that often, do you?). oh, and rumor has it that series 4 also wasn't that hot. oh well... maybe someday i'll cough up the cash for the dvd's.

from the i-emailed-myself-this-link-months-ago-with-the-intention-of-linking-it-in-my-blog department, here's every disclaimer in the book. could be handy to throw some of these in future employment contracts, i think... especially the bit about the mysterious "gluing force" which holds everything together but can't necessarily be depended on... yeah, that's the ticket. but on second thought: no.

album-of-the-day >>> shawn colvin's live 88 <<< good luck finding this album, even cdnow doesn't have it. recorded before her first album steady on, this is a simple live concert with just her voice and her guitar, and it's great just the way it is. apparently in 1995 a company called plump records re-released this recording which she used to self-market on cassette.

dreaming while you sleep  

tonight i'm thanking god for the anti-lock brakes on my outback sport (affectionately referred to as zooey)... just a few minutes ago, on the way home from benkay sushi (a monthly traditional follow-up to galilee youth mayhem at the robie gym), a guy just ran out in front of my car. the sheer stupidity of his running across a busy street with no regard for his personal safety, combined with the difficulty of seeing him amidst the rain and oncoming traffic, meant that i didn't see him until he was silhouetted by another's headlights as he was directly in front of my car... i missed him by inches, not feet, and he didn't even stop or look back or even seem to notice i had just come to a screeching halt, but just ran off into an alleyway. the lady in the car parked on the side of the road seemed to be laughing at me as i sat there dumbfounded for a moment, as if to say, "he does that all the time." yikes!

ainsley's in new york city this weekend to go to the brooklyn tabernacle with barbara, who thinks the world of this church and has wanted to take ains there for years, so i'm sure they'll have a good time. so, although i'm missing her a little bit, i'm celebrating her weekend away with a pint of ben & jerry's "new york super fudge chunk". ainsley also thinks that my reactions to stress might be a part of the tension and the headaches. my neurologist described a process called biofeedback which assists some people with controlling their own psychosomatic responses (good intro here and more details here) and explained how it had helped her son as early as age 11 to deal with adhd-type stress. when she described her son and other hypertense personalities that might benefit from biofeedback, ains was certain that i fit the profile. as i'm already expecting the new meds to be insufficient and/or inappropriate, after the two-week trial i think i'll give this biofeedback idea a shot. another possibility which i'm not quite warmed up to, however, is botox injections in the cramped muscles of my back and neck, which another doctor at that office is fond of and able to perform. again, i think i perfer the more natural, less medicated approach.

  • winwhatwhere is a somewhat-sneaky "computer activity monitor", not unlike backorifice.
  • visualroute attempts to trace an ip address back on the map by using whois, etc. to determine where hosting companies are located. and now you can use this tool online for free at symantec's security site.

i often wonder about the dubious idea of calling winwhatwhere a "security tool." i should think that many information security folks would be wary of using such a tool lest they be accused of entrapment when they do try to nab someone. but no doubt many others would enjoy this software for its "entertainment value" (a.k.a. possibly illicit use).</geek stuff>

spent some time yesterday fighting with the flight search engines looking for some last-minute tickets for ainsley. now, i used to be a travelocity devotee (in derence to microsoft and expedia), but in the past two months i've been loving orbitz. so today i sent them a suggestion that could change the world of travel reservations as we know it (for the better, course). i'm not sharing my recommendation with travelocity quite yet, because i want to give orbitz a chance first, but i will tell you.

As a seasoned budget-conscious traveller and online shopper, I've been very impressed with the Orbitz site since its launch, and I've used it often. Nonetheless, I'd like to make a suggestion that, if you implemented it, would make Orbitz.com the best flight search engine ever. You see, many (if not most) users of the flight search want to try several different options for price comparisons: for example, when I search for flights, I check up to 3 different nearby airports and weigh the price difference against the distance and inconvenience. As it is right now, I create a search from one airport, then hit the "Back" button and change to a different airport to re-run the search, and then the same process again a third time. Furthermore, I'll often weigh the results of modifying departure or return dates by one day in either direction, which means dozens more searches until I've found a price and time that I like. Now if your search engine would allow me to enter, for example, 2 different airports or 2 different return dates, and then do a side-by-side comparison of the results (or even list all the values together, but still sorted by price), I'd be so thrilled that I'd never use another flight reservation system again! I do believe that this option would spare your servers some cycles, as the number of searches would be reduced when people could get all their comparitive data in fewer requests... Of course, then you might have more people using your service, if it's really as useful as I would imagine it. So this would be a mutually beneficial improvement!

someday travellers everywhere will thank me.

the rub of love  

this whole syzygus idea is a grand experiment. the word "syzygus" (if you haven't heard) is greek for "yokefellows", which is english for "people who pull together and bear each others' burdens". i say it's an experiment because most of us, being fairly young, haven't seen many examples or real love in action (sadly enough, few churches demonstrate this in any meaningful way). when i say "real love" here i don't mean the late beatles song, and i don't mean the whole man-woman luv thang: i mean the kind of self-sacrificing, all-important love that jesus showed us. syzygus is an experiment because we're actually trying to live out this kind of love: when someone is in need, we respond.

of course, this hasn't always been the case. for nearly three years we've been growing together, but i wouldn't say we've been bearing each others' burdens too well; but now it seems we're learning how to serve, and it really is a joy. and now we're even beginning to make a habit of it, and i do hope it continues. it's amazing to hear a need and see that people are already, seemingly automatically, responding... for example, nathan has become the "car man"—when anyone in the group speaks of car troubles, nathan is soon under the hood and gathering others to help him troubleshoot and fix. love should be so natural, so commonplace, so free...

this love is also hard to figure out. god seems to have a handle on how love should work, but humans are so far from it at the start. the idea of self-sacrifice certainly doesn't come natural, and the commitment must be remade again and again. and then so often we know that something must be done, but we don't know how to do it. such was the situation tonight, as one of our number needs some help, and we are at a loss as to how to best help her, but we're trying.

if perchance some sunday evening you're driving by a denny's in portland and you see a rowdy bunch of twenty-somethings standing around in the parking lot alternately laughing, crying, hugging or dancing, there's no need to worry: they're just trying to figure out what it means to love as god does.

here's the obligatory "happy new year" message. yes, i know the date on the posting says it's already the third of january.

you know, i often wonder about all the hoopla (yes, hoopla) we put into celebrating special days such as new year's. i suppose there's some value in demarking the day as a point of passage—out with the old, in with the new—along with reflecting on the past and making commitments for the future. but then again, it's just another day, no different than the day before or after. not unlike birthdays.

my 26th birthday was a week and a half ago. i forgot to mention it here because, well, it's not all that significant to me. you see, i was born on christmas eve, so celebrations of my birthday are overshadowed by a certain holiday which immediately follows. oh well.

how often do you think you lie? how many times a day do you answer the question, "how are you doing?" are you truthful each time?

in america right now, the question "how's it going?" has become a standard informal greeting. often times it's not even meant to be answered—two guys will pass each other in the hall, and both with mutter "how's it going?" with half a grin, but no one will answer the question. but if you do—if you're one of the people who does answer this question—your answer is likely to be "fine" or "great, how 'bout you?" you're not supposed to be honest here; there just isn't the time. "well, jim, i got up this morning and stubbed my toe on the radiator, and it's been all downhill from there... in fact, just five minutes ago i spilled an entire cup of coffee on my boss'es wife." nope, no one cares.

but that deal is okay with me. you see, i'd rather not tell you anyway. don't worry, it's not you—i'm just careful with who i give that kind of personal information to. sometimes i think i ought to be even more careful. (let me explain.) for example, earlier this week i told a friend how frustrated and generally blue i've been recently, because i really needed to let it out. (you understand that.) but throughout the week he keeps asking me how i'm doing, and not letting me squirm away with some slough-off answer. i know he's doing it because he genuinely cares about me, and i should be happy about that; but really i'd rather not be bothered about it again. i mean, what if for the first time in days i was actually feeling pretty good about myself, and then suddenly he reminded me that i'm really unstable and weak? i'm fine, really... i can look after myself. i suddenly think: "why did i tell you in the first place? i should have known you'd use it against me later!"

you see, this is yet another reason why even my own mother has called me "fiercely independent." that sounds like a good thing to me—it sounds like i'm self-reliant and strong. but underneath that somewhere it means i'm just afraid to admit any bit of my dependence on others.

i'm fine, really. i'm fine.

the third writer in the set, andrew sullivan, is right on when he points out that "one of the problems in this culture is our inability to talk about difference without implying inequality." you know, it's obvious to me that men and women are different... and i think that's a good thing, and that's something to enjoy. i like women because they are altogether different then me and other men—they think differently; they act differently; they're motivated differently—that's interesting and exciting to me. but for someone to suggest that when i use the word "different" i mean that i value women less then men is ludicrous. you mean to tell me that when grover ran back and forth across the little twelve-inch black-and-white television screen hollering, "saaame! diffferent!" that some kids just didn't get it? how "different" do you have to be to miss the point?

elisabeth elliot has much to say on this topic in her book the mark of a man (and presumably in it's companion book, let me be a woman, although i haven't read it and therefore cannot confirm). she encourages the reader to enjoy the differences between the sexes because god created them that way and saw that it was—and still is—good, and moreover, she challenges us to be real men (or women), to work together in the best of those unique roles. how controversial! how backwards! or perhaps avant-garde? or is it fundamental?

concerning my agreement with bible study fellowship's statement of faith
i find bsf's statement of faith to be a reasonable summary of the essential tenets of the christian faith leading into an understanding of salvation through christ alone; for the most part, i am in full agreement. however, there is a single phrase in the ninth paragraph referring to an "age of accountability"; the implications of this idea cause me some concern. to this point in my understanding of the scriptures, i have found not a bit of evidence that god has selected a "cut-off" age before which a human is presumed innocent of any offense toward himself (that is, sin). rather, the bible clearly states that the only path to reconciliation with god is a conscious, personal decision to call on jesus for salvation through his death and resurrection--a point which is emphasized elsewhere in bsf's statement of faith. the invention of the concept of the "age of accountability" seems to me a softening of the hard truth of the gospel, intended for hearers who cannot accept the total sovereignty of god in choosing who he will or will not save. it frightens me that an organization intent on understanding the Bible would choose to make such a concession to weak theology that is not founded upon the word of god.
therefore, if i am to participate as a discussion leader of the local chapter of bsf, i ask to make exception to the clause in question, and refuse to teach in accordance with the implications thereof. if the elders of bsf find this a matter of disagreement, then i ask that you accept the immediate removal of my application for leadership within the organization.

at least today had an enjoyable challenge, so it was fun to work on that all afternoon. bill and i actually started working out the ideas yesterday, but we got right down to making a demo today, because he's going on vacation next week and before that he wants to prove to his boss that it can and will be done. the project is to make a flexible, self-sustaining system which can display all kinds of static and dynamic content on a projection screen they have set up in the factory (the Fab, as it's called in the semiconductor industry). recently, they set up the projector with simple, static PowerPoint slides, but someone got the big idea that we need to have live statistics on production updated 24x7x365. so, we've put together a system involving a single perl cgi and a web page fortified with client-side javascript, which together get a listing of the contents of a specific directory on the web server and roll through the content as a slide show. the scripts accept multiple content formats, including pre-built web pages or acrobat pdf's to more complex pieces such as excel spreadsheets and charts with live database refresh, which need an html wrapper built before the slide show will display them properly. thus, the end result is that the managers who want to put content in that slide show don't need to do anything special with their files to make them work, they just drop the files in the directory and our script does the rest. so, we don't need to do anything to make their data work, and there's no server component which we'd have to fix if it were to fail in the middle of the night. cool, eh? some people pay thousands of dollars for proprietary slideshow and content-generation programs, and we made our own in a couple hours...
